text: Thanks <@UDJ2TKB99>, the Widdows et al. link is very interesting, and makes a good stab at one of the most difficult problems, of building ontologies retroactively which previously I'd only seen tackled by "Semprola", Oli Sharpe's system which I mentioned in the other thread. I'd like to get some more technical detail on how the "roles" system is implemented and interpreted in practice, and perhaps even some source code : P The "noms" project seems to concentrate on the less interesting part of the problem, that is, how can we assure the integrity and availability of the data, the problem subset that we see tackled, for example, in the current incarnation of the "Dat" project - <https://datproject.org/> . It's great that our case studies also focus on visualizing wildlife sightings, got a few links to those followup papers?

attachments.title: Dat Project - A Community-Driven Web Protocol
attachments.text: Dat is the nonprofit-backed technology & community for building apps of the future.
attachments.fallback: Dat Project: Dat Project - A Community-Driven Web Protocol

I'd like to get some more technical detail on how the "roles" system is implemented and interpreted in practice, and perhaps even some source code : P The "noms" project seems to concentrate on the less interesting part of the problem, that is, how can we assure the integrity and availability of the data, the problem subset that we see tackled, for example, in the current incarnation of the "Dat" project -

text:
Thanks for the kind words on the paper, <@UCUSW7WVD> - indeed as you suggest, a program addition operator for arbitrary code is not workable, under the "black box" model. This is why we propose the abolition of program code as currently constituted - you can check out the parallel paper at <https://github.com/amb26/papers/raw/master/onward-2016/onward-2016.pdf> on the "Open Authorial Principle" for positive and negative constraints on how this replacement for code will need to be organised. Indeed it must operate on the "white box" principles you suggest - also note section 5.4 which explains that our program algebra is not like others which have been proposed, in being primarily decompositional rather than compositional. The OAP I think offers helpful economics and models of how the adopting community can "mess with the guts" of adopted artefacts whilst i) maintaining a relationship with the upstream community, ii) not necessarily disrupting the upstream community's artefacts.
Indeed comprehensibility is a key virtue underpinning all authorial activities, an important prerequisite of which is visibility/addressibility.
I should stop saying "indeed" but my 2-yr-old son has recently adopted it as an idiom from his favorite TV character, Flop.

on the "Open Authorial Principle" for positive and negative constraints on how this replacement for code will need to be organised. Indeed it must operate on the "white box" principles you suggest - also note section 5.4 which explains that our program algebra is not like others which have been proposed, in being primarily decompositional rather than compositional. The OAP I think offers helpful economics and models of how the adopting community can "mess with the guts" of adopted artefacts whilst i) maintaining a relationship with the upstream community, ii) not necessarily disrupting the upstream community's artefacts.
Indeed comprehensibility is a key virtue underpinning all authorial activities, an important prerequisite of which is visibility/addressibility.
I should stop saying "indeed" but my 2-yr-old son has recently adopted it as an idiom from his favorite TV character, Flop.

text:
<@UEH6T3RJB> I've been doing my own literature review of the MAYA work to refresh my memories—I'm glad you're finding some ideas in there. As for source code/running systems, I've reached out to former coworkers to understand the current state of things and what I can direct people to or potentially share from my own archives. Here are a few papers with more details on "roles":

• Roles in the universal database: Data and metadata in a distributed semantic network: <https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Dominic_Widdows/publication/228938561_Roles_in_the_universal_database_Data_and_metadata_in_a_distributed_semantic_network/links/0912f509937ef0e153000000/Roles-in-the-universal-database-Data-and-metadata-in-a-distributed-semantic-network.pdf>
• Managing distributed collaboration in a peer-to-peer network: <https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Dominic_Widdows/publication/220830033_Managing_Distributed_Collaboration_in_a_Peer-to-Peer_Network/links/5481f3410cf2e5f7ceab10ff.pdf>
• Collaborative Annotation that Lasts Forever: Using Peer-to-Peer Technology for Disseminating Corpora and Language Resources: <https://www.researchgate.net/publication/228725378_Collaborative_annotation_that_lasts_forever_Using_peer-to-peer_technology_for_disseminating_corpora_and_language_resources/download>
• And here's a link to a figure in another paper depicting a wildlife usage (as I recall it was a limited test): <https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Visualization-of-sightings-of-the-Florida-Panther_fig3_242396923>

text: <@UEH6T3RJB> - yes, all understanding is misunderstanding, if I misunderstand correctly? :smile: Perhaps all we can hope for is for communication to be compatible, but our internal cognition is...impossible to compare directly. Seems similar to how I don't really know if anyone else senses the color 'red' the exact same way as me. I'm looking forward to reading the book.

elements.text: - yes, all understanding is misunderstanding, if I misunderstand correctly?

Perhaps all we can hope for is for communication to be compatible, but our internal cognition is...impossible to compare directly. Seems similar to how I don't really know if anyone else senses the color 'red' the exact same way as me. I'm looking forward to reading the book.

text:
Thanks for the great links and feedback! I hadn't actually thought of the rationale you gave for restarts. It makes sense though. A far more tolerable, hence more common, microcosm of the "try reinstalling Windows" shrug-of-the-shoulders "solution". Too complex to reason about => destroy everything and start again from scratch, which is at least a well-understood state.

I've just added a short bit to the end I somehow didn't think to include, until a mention of "aggressively pushed updates" in the one of the above papers brought up some unpleasant memories and fire in my heart. *Now* it feels officially finished :slightly_smiling_face:
